Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Looking at the event log, the key activities are OR, MS, QS, AS, IQC, TST, RT, PK, LB, DP, D. From the cases, I can see that: Every case starts with OR, then MS, then QS, then AS. So the sequence OR -> MS -> QS -> AS is fixed at the beginning.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: After AS, theres a pattern with IQC and possibly repeating AS. In case 1: AS -> IQC -> AS -> ... In case 3: AS -> IQC -> IQC -> AS -> IQC -> AS -> ... So it seems that after AS, you can have IQC, and then either go back to AS or proceed.

Name: Pattern Recognition - IND
Text: But in case 4, theres no IQC at all: OR -> MS -> QS -> AS -> TST -> ... So IQC is optional?

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: So perhaps after the initial AS, theres a loop that involves IQC and possibly AS. But if IQC is not needed, then you go to TST.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: After TST, in some cases theres RT, which then goes back to TST. For example, case 1: TST -> RT -> TST -> PK. Case 2: TST -> PK. So after TST, theres a possible RT, which leads back to TST. This is clearly a loop: TST can be followed by RT and then TST again, or proceed to PK. So the pattern is: TST -> (RT -> TST)* -> PK Which fits the POWL loop operator: * (TST, RT)

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: LB can be skipped in some cases (like case 2).

Name: Hypothesis Generation - IND
Text: The AS-IQC block is: AS -> (IQC -> AS)* -> TST

Name: Validation - NE
Text: In case 3: AS -> IQC -> IQC -> AS -> IQC -> AS -> TST. This has two IQCs before the first AS repetition, which doesnt fit (IQC -> AS)

Name: Backtracking - PE
Text: If we set A = AS, B = IQC, then * (AS, IQC) means: Do AS Then either exit the loop or do IQC then AS again. In case 4: do AS (exit loop) -> TST. Good. In case 1: do AS, then do IQC then AS again, then exit loop -> TST. Correct.

Name: Validation - IND
Text: In case 3: AS, IQC, IQC, AS, IQC, AS, TST. With * (AS, IQC): First AS Then, do IQC then AS (first loop body) Then, do IQC then AS (second loop body) Then exit to TST. But in case 3, after the first AS, we have two IQCs before the first AS repetition: AS -> IQC -> IQC -> AS. This doesnt fit, because B in the loop is IQC (a single activity), but here we have multiple IQCs.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Given the complexity, perhaps the intended model is to have a loop between AS and IQC, with * (AS, IQC), even though it doesnt perfectly fit the data with multiple IQCs, or perhaps the multiple IQCs are considered concurrent or something.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The main sequence is: OR -> MS -> QS -> [AS-loop] -> [TST-loop] -> PK -> [LB-choice] -> DP -> D Where: AS-loop = * (AS, IQC) TST-loop = * (TST, RT) LB-choice = X (LB, silent)

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Verifying with cases: Case 4: AS_loop just AS, TST_loop just TST, LB_choice LB. Good. Case 2: AS_loop AS -> IQC -> AS, TST_loop TST, LB_choice silent. Good. Case 1: AS_loop AS -> IQC -> AS, TST_loop TST -> RT -> TST, LB_choice LB. Good.
